results.query: Compare Mining and Manufacturing indices for 2023-24 Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you compare the Mining and Manufacturing indices for 2023-24. Let me fetch this data from the MoSPI API.

Based on the Index of Industrial Production (IIP) data for 2023-24, here's a comparison of Mining and Manufacturing indices:

Overall Performance:

Key Findings:

Manufacturing had a higher absolute index value (144.7 vs 128.9), but Mining showed stronger growth at 7.5% compared to Manufacturing's 5.5% growth rate.

Within Manufacturing, notable performers included:

Strong Growth Sectors:

Weak or Negative Growth Sectors:

Overall, both sectors showed positive growth in 2023-24, with Mining slightly outpacing Manufacturing in terms of growth rate, though Manufacturing maintained a higher absolute index level indicating greater production relative to the base year 2011-12.

results.query: Show Primary Goods, Capital Goods and Intermediate Goods performance in 2022-23 Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you get the IIP (Index of Industrial Production) data for Primary Goods, Capital Goods, and Intermediate Goods for 2022-23.

Here's the performance of Primary Goods, Capital Goods, and Intermediate Goods in 2022-23 (base year 2011-12=100):

Primary Goods

Capital Goods

Intermediate Goods

Capital Goods showed the strongest growth at 13.1%, followed by Primary Goods at 7.5%. Intermediate Goods had more modest growth at 3.8%. In terms of absolute index values, Intermediate Goods had the highest at 149.4, while Capital Goods remained close to the base year level at 100.3.

results.query: How is mining, manufacturing, electricity and primary goods doing in 2023-24? Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you get comprehensive data on India's mining, manufacturing, electricity and primary goods performance for 2023-24. Let me access the MoSPI API to gather this information.

For your query about mining, manufacturing, electricity and primary goods in 2023-24, I'll use the Index of Industrial Production (IIP) dataset, which tracks these sectors.

Perfect! Now I'll fetch the data for mining, manufacturing, electricity, and primary goods for 2023-24.

Based on the official MoSPI data, here's how these sectors performed in 2023-24:

Mining grew strongly at 7.5%, with an index of 128.9. This robust performance suggests healthy extraction activities across coal, minerals, and other mining operations.

Manufacturing showed moderate growth of 5.5% overall (index: 144.7). Within manufacturing, the performance was mixed. Strong performers included basic metals (11.6% growth), motor vehicles (11.6%), other transport equipment (13.9%), and pharmaceuticals (8.0%). However, several subsectors struggled, particularly wearing apparel (-14.1%), computer and electronic products (-11.3%), and tobacco products (-8.3%).

Electricity posted solid growth of 7.1% with an index of 198.3, reflecting increased power generation to support economic activity.

Primary Goods (which includes mining and the quarrying sector along with electricity and some manufacturing items for primary use) grew at 6.1%, reaching an index of 147.7.

Overall, 2023-24 saw positive industrial growth across these core sectors, with mining and electricity leading the way. Manufacturing was more varied, with capital-intensive and infrastructure-related industries like basic metals and transport equipment performing particularly well, while some consumer-facing segments like apparel and electronics faced headwinds.

I'll help you find the sectoral categories available in the MoSPI datasets for 2019-20 and 2020-21. Let me start by checking what datasets are available.

Now let me check which datasets have sectoral breakdowns. The most comprehensive sectoral data would likely be in:

Let me start with NAS to see the sectoral categories:

Good! Now let me get the metadata for Gross Value Added (indicator_code=1) which will show all the sectoral categories:

Perfect! I can see all the sectoral categories. Now let me also check ASI to see the industrial classification structure:

Perfect! Now I have all the sectoral categories from both datasets. Let me present this information to you in a clear format.

Based on the MoSPI datasets, here are the sectoral classifications available:

Broad Industry Classification:

Sub-Industries (for detailed breakdown):

ASI provides much more granular industrial classification at 2-digit, 3-digit, and 4-digit levels using NIC 2008:

Major 2-Digit Sectors (30 manufacturing sectors):

The ASI classification extends to 83 three-digit categories and 256 four-digit categories for highly detailed industrial analysis.

Both datasets have data available for 2019-20 and 2020-21. Would you like me to extract specific data for any of these sectors for those years?

results.query: Compare all use-based categories for the year 2018-19 Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you compare all use-based categories for 2018-19. Let me start by finding the right dataset in the MoSPI API.

Based on your query about "use-based categories," this refers to the Index of Industrial Production (IIP) dataset, which classifies industrial production into use-based categories like basic goods, capital goods, intermediate goods, consumer durables, and consumer non-durables.

Let me get the available indicators for IIP:

Now let me get the metadata for IIP. For 2018-19 data, I'll use base year 2011-12 (the most recent base year that would cover 2018-19) and annual frequency:

Perfect! I can see all the use-based categories. Now let me fetch the data for all use-based categories for 2018-19:

Here's a comparison of all use-based categories for 2018-19:

Infrastructure/Construction Goods led with the highest index at 141.7 and strongest growth at 7.3%, indicating robust activity in construction and infrastructure sectors.

Consumer Non-durables had the second-highest index at 145.5 with 4.0% growth, reflecting steady demand for essential consumer goods like food products, toiletries, and other daily necessities.

Consumer Durables showed an index of 130.4 with 5.5% growth, indicating healthy consumer spending on items like appliances, electronics, and vehicles.

Intermediate Goods registered an index of 126.2 but had the slowest growth at just 0.9%, suggesting weaker demand from manufacturing sectors using these inputs.

Primary Goods (basic industrial materials) had an index of 126.1 with 3.5% growth, showing moderate expansion in mining and basic manufacturing materials.

Capital Goods had the lowest index at 108.4 with 2.7% growth, indicating subdued investment in machinery and equipment by industries during this period.

The data shows that in 2018-19, infrastructure and consumer-oriented sectors performed well, while investment goods and intermediate manufacturing inputs showed more modest growth, suggesting a consumption-driven rather than investment-driven industrial expansion.

results.query: Show me Electricity and Mining trends from 2015-16 to 2024-25 Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you find electricity and mining trends from 2015-16 to 2024-25 using the MoSPI API. Let me start by exploring what datasets are available.

Based on the API overview, I can see that the IIP (Index of Industrial Production) dataset tracks mining and electricity sectors. Let me get the available indicators.

Good, IIP uses categories. Let me get the metadata to see what's available. I'll use the most recent base year (2011-12) and annual frequency to see trends over the years.

Perfect! I can see Mining (category_code: 1) and Electricity (category_code: 3) are available. Now let me fetch the data for both sectors from 2015-16 to 2024-25.

Great! I've retrieved the electricity and mining trends data. Here's what the data shows:

The mining sector showed steady but modest growth over this period:

The mining sector experienced a significant contraction in 2020-21 due to the pandemic, followed by a robust recovery with 12.2% growth in 2021-22. Recent years show continued expansion, though the growth rate has moderated.

The electricity sector demonstrated stronger and more consistent growth:

The electricity sector proved more resilient during the pandemic with only a marginal decline. It has shown impressive growth in recent years, with the index nearly doubling from 133.8 in 2015-16 to 208.6 in 2024-25. The sector achieved its highest growth rate of 8.9% in 2022-23.

Key Takeaway: Both sectors were impacted by COVID-19 in 2020-21, but electricity showed greater resilience and has grown more rapidly overall, reflecting India's expanding energy needs and infrastructure development.

results.query: Compare Manufacturing and General index performance during COVID years 2019-20, 2020-21, 2021-22 Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you compare the Manufacturing and General index performance during the COVID years. Let me fetch this data from the MoSPI API.

For Manufacturing and General index performance, I need to use the IIP (Index of Industrial Production) dataset.

Perfect! Now I'll fetch the data for Manufacturing (category_code: 2) and General (category_code: 4) for the years 2019-20, 2020-21, and 2021-22.

I need to get more records to see all the data, including the overall Manufacturing index and data for other years.

Great! Now I have all the data. Let me present the comparison:

Here's the comparison of the Index of Industrial Production (IIP) for Manufacturing and General sectors across the three COVID-affected years:

2019-20 (Pre-COVID Impact)

Both indices were already showing slight contraction before the pandemic hit India.

2020-21 (Major COVID Impact)

This year saw the most severe impact, with both indices falling sharply. Manufacturing was hit slightly harder than the overall industrial sector, declining by 9.6% compared to 8.4% for the general index. The lockdowns, supply chain disruptions, and demand collapse severely affected industrial production.

2021-22 (Recovery Phase)

Both indices showed strong recovery, with growth rates exceeding 11%. Manufacturing actually bounced back slightly better (+11.8%) than the general index (+11.4%), surpassing pre-COVID levels.

Key Observations:

results.query: What is the gap between Capital Goods and Consumer goods categories in 2016-17? Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you find the gap between Capital Goods and Consumer Goods categories in 2016-17. Let me search the MoSPI database for this information.

The query about Capital Goods and Consumer Goods categories sounds like it's related to industrial production data, which would be in the IIP (Index of Industrial Production) dataset. Let me get the indicators for IIP.

Good, IIP uses categories directly. Let me get the metadata to see what categories and years are available. Since the query mentions 2016-17, I'll use base year 2011-12 which would cover that period.

Perfect! I can see that Capital Goods has category_code 6, and there are two consumer goods categories: Consumer Durables (category_code 9) and Consumer Non-durables (category_code 10). Let me fetch the data for 2016-17.

Based on the IIP data for 2016-17 (base year 2011-12), here are the index values:

The gap between Capital Goods and Consumer goods depends on which consumer category you're comparing:

If you're looking at overall consumer goods, Consumer Non-durables had the highest index at 126.5, showing that Capital Goods lagged behind consumer goods production by approximately 21-25 index points in 2016-17.

results.query: Show all categories except subcategories for latest year 2023-24 Respond in chat, not in an artifact.
results.response_text:
I'll help you get the categories for the latest year 2023-24. Let me start by exploring the MoSPI API to understand what datasets are available.

Now I can see the available datasets. To show you categories for 2023-24, I need to understand which dataset you're interested in. However, since you mentioned "categories" which is most commonly associated with either:

Let me check what's available for each. I'll start with WPI as it has the most detailed category structure:

Perfect! I can now see the WPI (Wholesale Price Index) structure for 2023-24. Let me fetch the data for all major groups (categories) for the latest available year in 2023-24. Since the data shows year 2024 is available, I'll get data for March 2024 (which would represent the 2023-24 fiscal year end):

Great! Now let me get the remaining data by requesting just the major group level (without subcategories). Let me make a more targeted request:

I see the data is still including subcategories. Let me extract just the group-level categories (without subgroups) from the data I've already received. Based on the metadata structure, here are all the major categories (Groups) for WPI in March 2024 (FY 2023-24):

Under Primary Articles:

Under Fuel & Power: 5. Coal - (data available) 6. Mineral oils - (data available) 7. Electricity - (data available)

Under Manufactured Products (15 groups): 8. Manufacture of food products - (data available) 9. Manufacture of beverages - (data available) 10. Manufacture of tobacco products - (data available) 11. Manufacture of textiles - (data available) 12. Manufacture of wearing apparel - (data available) 13. Manufacture of leather and related products - (data available) 14. Manufacture of wood and products of wood and cork - (data available) 15. Manufacture of paper and paper products - (data available) 16. Printing and reproduction of recorded media - (data available) 17. Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products - (data available) 18. Manufacture of pharmaceuticals, medicinal chemical and botanical products - (data available) 19. Manufacture of rubber and plastics products - (data available) 20. Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products - (data available) 21. Manufacture of basic metals - (data available) 22. Manufacture of fabricated metal products, except machinery and equipment - (data available)

Plus additional manufacturing groups for electronics, electrical equipment, machinery, motor vehicles, transport equipment, furniture, and other manufacturing.

The WPI data structure has 5 major groups at the highest level and 22 groups at the next level, with 90+ sub-groups and 1000+ individual items below that.
